This documentation has been collected and elaborated by MEDIA Salles on the basis of the information supplied by the following organisations: BAC Films, Buena Vista International, Cecchi Gori Group, Film Finders, Film Journal International, IMDB, MEDIA Salles  European Cinema Yearbook, MPAA, Scotia International Films, Unifrance, Variety, Vision Film Distribution. Each source is indicated beside the data pertaining to it.

With the aim of providing a wide overview of the situation and, at the same time, of obtaining the maximum possible precision, MEDIA Salles used the sources that seemed more complete and allowing an homogeneous treatment of data.

NEW YORK SCREENS

Variety November 16, 1998Expansion in the next few months marked by new plexes means more competition for both audiences and top noch product.

November 13, 1998 United Artists Theatre Circuit opened downtowns first megaplex with the promise of at least two of its 14 screens for "niche pics". UA Union Square is the first New York theater with stadium seating.

November 12, 1998 Brooklyn Academy of Music opened BAM Rose Cinemas fourplex, the first in Brooklyn dedicated to screening independent and foreign language pictures.

End of November 1998 Greenwich Village art houses Cinema Village will expand from one screen to three.

Thalia theater, uptown Manhattan, is dropping its program of Indian films in favor of indie titles with a multicultural flavor such as the self-distributed Naked Acts and Crossing Fields.

Landmark, the national specialized theater chain is said to be building a multiplex in downtown Manhattan, just down the street from the Angelika.

Six Screen Angelika, an art house has been playing more commercial titles since it was acquired two years ago by City Cinemas.

Lincoln Plaza Cinemas on Manhattans upper west side owned by Dan Talbot who also owns New Yorker Film Distribution allows films to play long enough to build word of mouth.

May 1998 merger of Sonys Loew Theatres unit and Cineplex Odeon promises to increase the number of screens devoted to specialized films.

Owner of cable TVs Bravo Channel and the Independent Channel, Cablevisions acquisition of Clearview Theatres has led some industry-ites to speculate that the Bravo or Independent Channel name could soon appear on some Manhattan theater marquees.

Sundance Film Festival has leveraged its well known name with a cable network and upcoming cinema chain, a joint venture with General Cinema.

Older theaters such as The Regency will be closing, single screen art houses Cinema Village, the Quad, and the upscale Paris expect to perform as usual though they may have to scramble more for product.

Non profit Film Forum in downtown Manhattan sees increased theater building as positive.

Nationwide, multiplex operators have not been particularly successful in mixing arthouse and commercial fare with the exception of New York theaters such as Sony Lincoln Square, the nations highest grossing theater which does give a niche pic the momentum to break out.

Landmark Theaters, the nations largest specialized circuit is making its first foray into New York City in a joint venture the Sunshine Amalgamedia. They will convert the 1898 Sunshine Theater, a former Yiddish vaudeville house on the Lower East Side, into a state of the art five screen art house to be named Sunshine Cinema and to open next summer. Landmark, the only specialized circuit with a national presence, has fifty one theaters representing 152 screens in eleven states. The company was acquired in April 1998 by Dallas based Silver Cinemas.

This paper has been prepared by the offices of MEDIA Salles, the project operating within the framework of the European Unions MEDIA II Programme and with the support of the Italian Government

The end objective of MEDIA Salles is to foster theatrical distribution of European audiovisual products.Thus the current initiatives from MEDIA Salles dovetail in a programme with a triple focus - distribution, promotion and information - and maximum combined effect.

distribution

MEDIA Salles' flagship initiative in the field of theatrical exhibition is the Euro Kids Network, joining cinemas which screen films for children and young people and/or schools, giving priority to European products. promotion

Under the banner of Focus on Europe, MEDIA Salles has created a promotional platform for European audiovisual product at major professional meetings worldwide. From Atlantic City to Singapore via Amsterdam, MEDIA Salles is present, organizing round tables and using trailers, screenings, video previews, publicity handouts and on-line information to raise the visibility of new European products with distributors and exhibitors around the world.

information

MEDIA Salles provides a unique information service on European cinema, freely accessible to private and corporate users worldwide.The European Cinema Yearbook is the annual survey of the exhibition industry in European countries both in and outside the Union, recording key trends and market factors across the continent by means of over 40 statistical indicators.The European Cinema On-line Database (accessible directly at MEDIA Salles' Internet Web site http://www.mediasalles.it) giving an overview of the European cinema industry, presenting more than 4,000 European films produced since 1995, and 9,000 companies handling production, distribution, foreign sales of European titles, and including theatres and exhibitors.These information tools are complemented by the Newsletter European Cinema Journal, issued four times a year on the occasion of the promotional events organised by MEDIA Salles.
